subject: testing for compile errors
msgSnippet: A while back I posted a question/suggestion about being able to test for compile-time erros.  Such testing is especially important in the presence of java
messageBody:
A while back I posted a question/suggestion about being able to test for
compile-time erros. Such testing is especially important in the
presence of java generics -- you want to be sure that some data types,
such as in method parameters, compile correctly, but others result in a
compile error. Testing these cases by hand defeats the whole purpose of
unit testing.

Is there any way to test for a compile time error in a JUnit test? Is
this something that would be impossible to add?

> From: "albsavoia" albsavoia@...
> Date: Sun May 28, 2006 10:24am(PDT)
> Subject: Re: JUnit vs. Agitator
>
> As co-founder and CTO of Agitar, I find the "JUnit vs. Agitator"
> subject heading very troubling - so I feel compelled to jump in.
>
> Agitator *complements* JUnit; it helps you in performing broad
> exploratory testing, and in identifying and persisting class and
> method invariants (amount many other things).
>
> I am a big fan and proponent of JUnit, and so is Agitar. As a matter
> of fact, we brought Kent Beck on board as an Agitar Fellow a couple of
> years ago. I also gave 2 JavaOne presentation on JUnit (not
> Agitator); one in 2004 and the last one just last week where I
> co-presented with Kent Beck himself. Agitator takes full advantage of
> any existing JUnit tests and our Dashboard product is also fully
> integrated with JUnit.
>
> So, don't think in terms of JUnit vs. Agitator, but in terms of what
> can Agitator do to complement my JUnit and TDD efforts. Of course, I
> believe it can do a lot - but I am hardly an impartial party :-).
>
> JUnit is great for TDD which, as some people noted, is more about
> design than testing. It's also great for crafting very specific test
> cases where you can use your intuition and understanding of the domain
> space and implementation to cover interesting scenarios and sequences.
>
> Agitator is great for exploratory testing, subjecting your code to all
> sorts of inputs - both valid and invalid - which helps you think about
> corner cases and conditions that you might have overlooked. It's also
> uniquely capable in discovering and enforcing class and method
> invariants (i.e. properties of the code that should *always* be true -
> as opposed to the more specific cases people typically write in JUnit).
>
> Bottom line: Think in terms of JUnit + Agitator and not JUnit vs.
> Agitator.
>
> Thanks,
>
> Alberto Savoia
>
>
>

>>My company is currently doing TDD and using JUnit for our unit
>>testing - both persistence testing and business logic testing. We
>>are now looking at Agitator and trying to determine if, and how, it
>>fits into our current practices. I was wondering how others have
>>decided to use Agitator (or not use it). Some of the issues we are
>>struggling with:
>>
>>1. Agitator looks like it can eliminate the need to write most JUnit
>>tests (except true persistence testing). The downside is that we
>>would be left with only Agitator config files that contain our
>>business logic assertions. This seems like a big leap to take, given
>>that if Agitar goes away, we have no JUnit.
>>
>>2. Agitator mocks and factories look easy to create, but look like
>>they are only useful in the context of Agitator. I couldn't use them
>>for other purposes (e.g. Fitnesse, JUnit).
>>
>>3. Having my business logic tests in JUnit means they are in an
>>understood format and things such as inputs and expected results are
>>clearly visible and grouped with each test. My impression of
>>Agitator is that this wouldn't be as clear.
>>

>
> This is Alberto jumping in again to set the record straight on
> Agitator ...
>
> Hi Joe, you might not remember me but we exchanged emails a couple of
> years ago, and I am a big fan of yours for all the work you have done
> to educate people about JUnit through your book and online presence.
>
> Anyway ... your description of using Agitator to complement TDD is
> spot-on (for people who do TDD) - thank you for jumping in and helping
> in setting the record straight. But you also state (I paraphrase):
> "Agitator does not help you identify design problems or motivate you
> to improve the design". We have actually found, somewhat
> serendipitously, that Agitator does indeed help you in identifying
> design problems and even provides you compelling motivations to
> address them (e.g. well designed code Agitates better).
>
> A simple example, of Agitator helping you improve your design is
> blogged on developertesting.com:
>
> http://www.developertesting.com/archives/month200402/20040226-TestDrivenDevelopmentAndAgitatorDrivenRefactoring.html
>
> Again, this does not mean that Agitator replaces TDD, but it can
> complement TDD efforts (our own Dashboard product was developed
> practicing TDD, pair-programming, etc., AND Agitator of course).
>
> Alberto

> Hi Alberto
>
> Keeping your impartial hat on ;-) ... if we removed the context of TDD
> would that change you view on the use of Agitator with JUnit?
>
> We are currently looking at defining Developer Testing within our
> organisation. I get the impression that current thinking is that I could
> use Agitator instead of JUnit. Now this may be correct But I am wondering
> how correct?
>
> It could be correct in the same way that I could rub two sticks together
> instead of using matches or it could be correct in that I could use matches
> instead of a lighter.
>
> Or do you see Agitator complementing JUnit in the same way whether you are
> using TTD or not?
>
> My current thinking is the two tools solve slightly different problems ...
> or they address testing is different ways. An example that comes to mind is
> in the Agitator tutorial. In reaching full agitation the observation that
> the length of product name is less than 20 revealed a bug. But as I saw
> that I thought ... but if I had a JUnit test testing the boundaries of name
> as specified would have been tested and that mistake highlighted
> immediately. Anyhow at the moment I am thinking that developers should
> start with JUnit or JUnit + Agitator and not simply just Agitator.
>
> Your thoughts?
>
>
> Thanks
